title: Headlam Hall in Teesdale near Durham is a popular spot for weddings
text:
2
View
comments
Rating:
There have been five weddings in as many days here at Headlam Hall in Teesdale, not far from Durham. One is moving through the gears as we pull up outside this huge Jacobean former private home that was converted to a hotel in 1978.
The live band is already playing Wonderful Tonight; tailcoats have been discarded, inhibitions abandoned; the smoking coterie outside the purpose-built hospitality wing is growing by the minute.
It takes a while to get our bearings. This is a resort set in four acres of immaculate gardens, a destination for families, sporty couples and OAPs looking for a treat. There’s a nine-hole golf course, a spa and indoor swimming pool, ornamental canal, tennis court and croquet lawn.
Headlam Hall is popular for weddings... so The Inspector checked out what all the fuss is about
Rooms are either stuffy-traditional in the main house or safe-contemporary in one of the annexes. We opt for the former, which turns out to be despairingly incongruous.
Somehow, the large four-poster doesn’t work with the cramped modern bathroom with cheap fixtures and fittings. Two of the three windows have been permanently sealed by coats of paint and the duvet has long outlived its fluffy days.

Share this article Share But there’s still something heart-warming going on, especially when sitting in the Great Hall before dinner with a great big glass of vino, the grand piano being played in the background. Staff are largely locals who seem to take pride in their jobs.
The Inspector wasn't blown away with the crab and avocado starter (file photo)
Dinner is served in the conservatory — an airless space bereft of atmosphere. Our crab and avocado (for me) and smoked salmon mousse (for her) starters taste and look just as they do off the ready-made shelf in Marks & Spencer. But our crusted rack of lamb is delicious.
We sleep soundly, but make it in good time for breakfast, where we are told to sit in an arid side room to the airless conservatory. The sun is screaming at us through the window.
‘I don’t think I can have breakfast here,’ I tell my wife. ‘Don’t be ridiculous,’ she says. ‘Just do something about it.’
So I ask a waiter if he can open the nearest window to our table — and he does. Whoosh!
But there’s nothing he can do to revive the decimated breakfast buffet — it’s pretty much all gone. Better to clear it away altogether than leave a few dishes of dregs.
And I just don’t get why you should ever have to pay extra for an espresso at breakfast. It’s like asking someone to pay extra for the mash when ordering sausage and mash.
Our spirits rise as we walk round the garden before leaving. Another wedding group will be here soon; or Rotary Club AGM.
